what: The Challenge of Fragmented Economic Data
title: Introducing the EconDataverse: A Universe of R Packages for Economic Data
text: Economic data essential research policy analysis, yet accessing efficiently R persistent challenge. Data scientists routinely spend time acquiring cleaning data actually analyzing . economists policymakers, especially developing countries, creates real barriers: expensive commercial data subscriptions, time-consuming manual processing, delays evidence-based decision-making. EconDataverse project, supported R Consortium ISC Grant, addresses challenges creating unified ecosystem R packages provide consistent, tidy access major economic data sources. package targets specific data source sharing common design philosophy: consistent function naming, tidy data formats, cross-source compatibility. result significantly less time spent data acquisition preparation. can install meta-package, provides access implemented data sources core helper packages, CRAN: Loading package attaches component packages one step: additionally use following packages data manipulation visualization:
code: install.packages("econdataverse") library(econdataverse) #> ── Attaching core EconDataverse packages ─────────── econdataverse 0.1.2.9000 ── #> ✔ econdatasets 0.1.0     ✔ oecdoda      0.1.0 #> ✔ econid       0.0.3     ✔ owidapi      0.1.1 #> ✔ econtools    0.1.0     ✔ uisapi       0.1.1 #> ✔ imfapi       0.1.2     ✔ wbids        1.1.3 #> ✔ imfweo       0.1.0     ✔ wbwdi        1.0.3 library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(forcats) library(ggplot2)

title: Introducing the EconDataverse: A Universe of R Packages for Economic Data
text: econdataverse currently includes following packages: Let’s see packages work practice.

title: Introducing the EconDataverse: A Universe of R Packages for Economic Data
text: Let us fetch GDP current USD selection countries: observation contains identifiers entities indicators. deliberately use consistent descriptive primary key column names (e.g., entity_id, indicator_id, series_id) across packages. simplifies joins makes data structures predictable across different data sources. convenient way add standardized entity names labeling plotting provided econid package: package website provides additional examples use cases. Now can use standardized labels easily visualize GDP trends:  econtools package provides convenience functions enrich existing data. instance, can easily add population column calculate GDP per capita: refer package documentation additional use cases.
code: gdp_data <- wdi_get(   indicators = "NY.GDP.MKTP.CD",   entities = c("USA", "CHN", "DEU", "IND", "JPN"),   start_year = 2000,   end_year = 2024 ) gdp_data #> # A tibble: 125 × 4 #>    entity_id indicator_id    year   value #>    <chr>     <chr>          <int>   <dbl> #>  1 CHN       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.22e12 #>  2 DEU       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.97e12 #>  3 IND       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 4.68e11 #>  4 JPN       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 4.97e12 #>  5 USA       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.03e13 #>  6 CHN       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.36e12 #>  7 DEU       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.97e12 #>  8 IND       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 4.85e11 #>  9 JPN       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 4.37e12 #> 10 USA       NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.06e13 #> # ℹ 115 more rows gdp_data <- standardize_entity(gdp_data, entity_id) #> Warning: Target column(s) "entity_id" share name(s) with output columns; original values #> will be used for matching then overwritten with standardized values. gdp_data #> # A tibble: 125 × 6 #>    entity_id entity_name   entity_type indicator_id    year   value #>    <chr>     <chr>         <chr>       <chr>          <int>   <dbl> #>  1 CHN       China         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.22e12 #>  2 DEU       Germany       economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.97e12 #>  3 IND       India         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 4.68e11 #>  4 JPN       Japan         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 4.97e12 #>  5 USA       United States economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.03e13 #>  6 CHN       China         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.36e12 #>  7 DEU       Germany       economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.97e12 #>  8 IND       India         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 4.85e11 #>  9 JPN       Japan         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 4.37e12 #> 10 USA       United States economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.06e13 #> # ℹ 115 more rows ggplot(gdp_data, aes(x = year, y = value, color = entity_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   labs(     title = "GDP in Current USD Over Time",     x = NULL,     y = NULL,     color = "Country"   ) +   scale_y_continuous(     labels = scales::label_dollar(scale = 1e-12, suffix = "T")   ) add_population_column(   gdp_data,   id_column = "entity_id",   date_column = "year" ) #> # A tibble: 125 × 7 #>    entity_id entity_name   entity_type indicator_id    year   value population #>    <chr>     <chr>         <chr>       <chr>          <int>   <dbl>      <dbl> #>  1 CHN       China         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.22e12 1262645000 #>  2 DEU       Germany       economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.97e12   82211508 #>  3 IND       India         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 4.68e11 1057922733 #>  4 JPN       Japan         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 4.97e12  126843000 #>  5 USA       United States economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2000 1.03e13  282162411 #>  6 CHN       China         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.36e12 1271850000 #>  7 DEU       Germany       economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.97e12   82349925 #>  8 IND       India         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 4.85e11 1077898575 #>  9 JPN       Japan         economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 4.37e12  127149000 #> 10 USA       United States economy     NY.GDP.MKTP.CD  2001 1.06e13  284968955 #> # ℹ 115 more rows

title: Introducing the EconDataverse: A Universe of R Packages for Economic Data
text: key benefit EconDataverse ability combine data different sources using shared design philosophy. wbwdi package provides World Development Indicators (WDI), observations entity year. wbids package provides International Debt Statistics (IDS), structured entity, counterpart, year. consistency allows two packages work seamlessly together. following examples, focus Thailand (ISO-3 country code “THA”). Understanding composition country’s debt—distinguishing total government debt external debt owed foreign creditors—helps assess fiscal vulnerability identify potential risks. begin comparing total government debt external debt time. Since IDS data reported USD, compute government debt combining central government debt percentage GDP (“GC.DOD.TOTL.GD.ZS”) total GDP USD (“NY.GDP.MKTP.CD”): Next, fetch total external debt IDS series “DT.DOD.DPPG.CD” across counterparts. counterpart “WLD” represents whole world used construct aggregate external debt levels. structure allows us distinguish total debt bilateral creditor exposures. can now visualize total government external debt Thailand:  key advantage IDS ability break external debt creditor, revealing holds country’s debt:  applications insights international debt data, see Teal Insights’ Guide Working World Bank International Debt Statistics.
code: government_debt <- wdi_get(   entities = "THA",   indicators = c("NY.GDP.MKTP.CD", "GC.DOD.TOTL.GD.ZS"),   start_year = 2014,   end_year = 2024,   format = "wide" ) |>   mutate(     debt = `GC.DOD.TOTL.GD.ZS` / 100 * `NY.GDP.MKTP.CD`,     type = "Government"   ) |>   select(entity_id, year, debt, type) external_debt <- ids_get(   entities = "THA",   series = "DT.DOD.DPPG.CD",   counterparts = "all",   start_year = 2014,   end_year = 2024 )  external_debt_total <- external_debt |>   filter(counterpart_id == "WLD") |>   select(entity_id, year, debt = value) |>   mutate(type = "External Debt")  debt_levels <- bind_rows(government_debt, external_debt_total) debt_levels |>   ggplot(aes(x = year, y = debt, color = type)) +   geom_line() +   labs(     x = NULL,     y = NULL,     color = "Debt Type",     title = "Total Government and External Debt in Thailand in Current USD"   ) +   scale_y_continuous(     labels = scales::label_dollar(scale = 1e-9, suffix = "B")   ) debt_breakdown <- external_debt |>   filter(counterpart_id != "WLD" & year == 2024) |>   left_join(     ids_list_counterparts(),     join_by(counterpart_id)   )  debt_breakdown |>   arrange(-value) |>   slice(1:5) |>   ggplot(aes(x = value, y = fct_reorder(counterpart_name, value))) +   geom_col() +   labs(     x = "External debt (USD)",     y = NULL,     title = "Top 5 Creditors of Thailand in 2024",     subtitle = "External debt stocks, public and publicly guaranteed"   ) +   scale_x_continuous(     labels = scales::label_dollar(scale = 1e-9, suffix = "B")   )

title: Introducing the EconDataverse: A Universe of R Packages for Economic Data
text: EconDataverse already demonstrating practical impact several Shiny applications: Debt Path Explorer: Helps policymakers climate-vulnerable countries simulate different sustainability targets climate policies affect long-term debt trajectories. Economic Outlook Explorer: Allows researchers interactively explore IMF World Economic Outlook projections across countries time horizons. Debt Network Visualizer: Enables exploration global lending networks, highlighting major creditors cross-country debt linkages.

title: Introducing the EconDataverse: A Universe of R Packages for Economic Data
text: project collaboration : Christoph Scheuch — Co-creator Tidy Finance, Lecturer Humboldt-University Berlin Teal Emery — Founder Teal Insights, Adjunct Lecturer Johns Hopkins SAIS Christopher C. Smith — President Promptly Technologies welcome contributions! can: Use packages provide feedback via GitHub Issues Contribute code following contribution guidelines Spread word sharing colleagues work economic data want request development package data source choice, feel free get touch Christoph Scheuch.

title: Introducing the EconDataverse: A Universe of R Packages for Economic Data

what: Easily Load and Install the EconDataverse
title: Easily Load and Install the EconDataverse
text: ‘EconDataverse’ universe open-source packages work seamlessly economic data. package designed make easy install load multiple ‘EconDataverse’ packages single step. Learn ‘EconDataverse’ econdataverse.org.

title: Easily Load and Install the EconDataverse
text: can install econdataverse CRAN via: can install development version econdataverse GitHub :

title: Easily Load and Install the EconDataverse
text: library(econdataverse) load core EconDataverse packages: econdatasets, downloading selected datasets preprocessed ‘EconDataverse’ packages. econid, standardizing identifiers. econtools, combining data sources. imfapi, International Monetary Fund API. imfweo, International Monetary Fund World Economic Outlook (WEO). oecdoda, OECD Official Development Assistance (ODA). owidapi, World Data API. uisapi, UNESCO Institute Statistics API. wbids, World Bank International Debt Statistics (IDS). wbwdi, World Bank World Development Indicators (WDI).
code: library(econdataverse) #> ── Attaching core EconDataverse packages ──────────────── econdataverse 0.1.2 ── #> ✔ econdatasets 0.1.0     ✔ oecdoda      0.1.0 #> ✔ econid       0.0.3     ✔ owidapi      0.1.1 #> ✔ econtools    0.1.0     ✔ uisapi       0.1.1 #> ✔ imfapi       0.1.2     ✔ wbids        1.1.3 #> ✔ imfweo       0.1.0     ✔ wbwdi        1.0.3

title: Easily Load and Install the EconDataverse
text: Contributions econdataverse welcome! ’d like contribute, please follow steps: Create issue: making changes, create issue describing bug feature ’re addressing. Fork repository: receiving supportive feedback package authors, fork repository GitHub account. Create branch: Create branch changes descriptive name. Make changes: Implement bug fix feature. Test changes: Run tests ensure changes don’t break existing functionality. Submit pull request: Push changes fork submit pull request main repository.
